en_results_raw: as I lay in bed, the sunlight streaming through the blinds, casting an annoyingly cheerful glow on the walls, and my best friend, Rachel, bouncing around the room, chattering excitedly about the upcoming dance, completely oblivious to my apathy. She was like a human version of a sugary candy, all bubbly and annoyingly enthusiastic, and I couldn't help but feel a twinge of guilt for not sharing her excitement. I mean, it was prom, the supposed highlight of high school, and I was supposed to be thrilled, but all I could think about was how I'd rather be anywhere else, doing anything else, than attending a night of overpriced dresses, awkward small talk, and forced smiles. Rachel, on the other hand, was practically bouncing off the walls, her eyes shining with excitement as she showed me her dress, a bright pink monstrosity that looked like it belonged on a kindergartener, not a high school student. I forced a smile, trying to play along, but inside, I was screaming, "Get me out of here!"

You see, when I was a teenager, I stumbled upon an old, mysterious-looking book in the attic of our family's ancestral home. It was bound in a strange, scaly material that felt like it was alive under my touch, and the cover was adorned with symbols that seemed to shift and writhe like living serpents. I remember feeling an inexplicable pull towards it, as if it was calling to me, and I knew in that moment that my life was about to change forever. I spent the next few weeks studying the book, pouring over its yellowed pages and trying to decipher the cryptic language that seemed to hold the secrets of the universe. And then, one fateful night, I made the discovery that would change everything: a hidden compartment in the book that contained a small, crystal orb that glowed with an otherworldly energy. It was then that I realized that the book was more than just a simple artifact - it was a key to unlocking the doors of perception, a gateway to other dimensions and realities that lay beyond our own. And that's when I began to experiment with the orb, using it to travel to other worlds and experience things that most people can only dream of. But as you can probably guess, it's not all fun and games - there are risks involved, and I've had to be careful not to get caught up in the infinite possibilities that the orb presents. But I'll tell you this, Dad: it's been a wild ride, and I'm not sure I'd trade it for anything in the world.

en_results_raw: The hallway, her sneakers squeaking on the worn linoleum. She stopped in front of my room, hesitated for a moment, then pushed the door open with her elbow, not looking at me. I felt a surge of anxiety as she stepped inside, her eyes scanning the space with a mixture of curiosity and disdain. The smell of fresh paint and turpentine hung in the air, mingling with the faint scent of last night's Chinese takeout. Margo's gaze landed on the half-finished catfish sculpture on my desk, and her expression changed from neutral to intrigued. She walked over to it, running her fingers over the rough texture of the paint, her eyes never leaving the artwork. "What's this?" she asked, her voice low and even, but with a hint of amusement. I shrugged, feeling a mix of defensiveness and pride. "Just something I'm working on," I said, trying to sound nonchalant. Margo raised an eyebrow, her eyes sparkling with curiosity. "A catfish?" she repeated, her voice dripping with skepticism. I nodded, feeling a surge of determination. "Yeah, a catfish." She turned to face me, a small smile playing on her lips. "You know, I never would have pegged you as the artistic type." I felt a flush rise to my cheeks, but I tried to play it cool. "Hey, I'm full of surprises," I said, trying to sound confident. Margo chuckled, her eyes crinkling at the corners. "I'll say." She turned back to the catfish, her fingers tracing the shape of the fish's fins. "You know, it's actually kind of...good." I felt a rush of excitement at her words, and my pulse quickened. Maybe, just maybe, I was onto something here. Maybe this art thing wasn't so bad after all.

I could feel the warmth of her skin through the thin fabric of my shirt, a sensation that made my heart skip a beat. We stood there for what felt like an eternity, the only sound the soft rustle of leaves in the gentle breeze. It was as if time itself had slowed down, and all that existed was this moment, this connection between us. I didn't dare move, didn't dare break the spell that had been cast. But eventually, she spoke, her voice barely above a whisper, "I'm sorry." I turned to her, my eyes locking onto hers, searching for answers, searching for a glimpse of what was going on behind those piercing green eyes. But all I saw was a deep sadness, a sense of loss that seemed to weigh her down. I reached out, my hand brushing against hers, a gentle touch that seemed to spark a flicker of hope. "What's wrong?" I asked, my voice low and gentle, trying not to startle her. She looked away, her eyes drifting towards the houses, the streets, the world beyond our little bubble. "It's just...I don't know if I can do this anymore," she said, her voice cracking with emotion. I pulled her closer, my arms wrapping around her, holding her tight. "Do what?" I asked, my voice muffled against her hair. But she just shook her head, her body trembling in my arms. I held her tighter, trying to offer what little comfort I could, but deep down, I knew that this was just the beginning of a long and difficult conversation.

en_results_raw: It was a peculiar sensation, as if time itself had slowed down, and all that existed was the two of us, suspended in this moment of anticipation. The air was thick with unspoken words, and I could feel the weight of our unspoken connection. Margo's eyes seemed to be drawing me in, pulling me deeper into their depths, and I found myself getting lost in the endless blue, like a sailor navigating through uncharted waters. The sound of my own heartbeat was the only sound I could hear, a steady drumbeat that seemed to be counting down the seconds until... until what, I wasn't quite sure. But I knew it was something important, something that would change everything. And as the seconds ticked by, I felt my heart racing with excitement and trepidation, my mind racing with possibilities.

en_second_half: it shut with a drawstring; the streetlight lit up the sharp features of her pale face. Maybe we were both ninjas, but only she had the outfit.
en_results: The scarf around her neck, and adjusted her mask, trying to blend in with the dimly lit alleyway. "I'm just saying, if we're both ninjas, then
en_results_raw: The scarf around her neck, and adjusted her mask, trying to blend in with the dimly lit alleyway. "I'm just saying, if we're both ninjas, then why do I have to be the one sneaking around like a total amateur?" she whispered, her eyes scanning the rooftops for any sign of their target. Meanwhile, I was busy trying to untangle my shoelaces, which had somehow managed to knot themselves into a particularly complex mess. "It's because I'm the one who's been training for years," I replied, attempting to sound confident, "and you're just a... um, ninja-in-training." Margo shot me a skeptical look, but I could tell she was trying not to laugh. We had been friends since childhood, and I knew her well enough to recognize the hint of a smile playing on her lips. As we continued to creep through the shadows, I couldn't help but wonder what we were doing here, sneaking around the city at midnight, on a mission to retrieve a mysterious artifact. It sounded like something out of a bad action movie, but Margo had sworn it was real, and I had to admit, I was curious. Little did I know, this was only the beginning of a night that would change everything.

en_first_half: “Okay,” she said. “Memorize the map.” By far the most terrifying part of the half-mile-long journey Margo had plotted for us was the moat. SeaWorld was shaped like a triangle. One side was protected by a road, which Margo figured was regularly patrolled by night watchmen. The second side
en_second_half: was guarded by a lake that was at least a mile around, and the third side had a drainage ditch; from the map, it looked to be about as wide as a two-lane road. And where there are water-filled drainage ditches near lakes in Florida, there are often alligators.
en_results: was a steep cliff, but the third side, the one we were approaching, was the moat. It was a deep, murky waterway that surrounded the entire park, and Margo had deemed it the most challenging obstacle to overcome. The water was home to a variety of marine life, including
en_results_raw: The second side was a steep cliff, but the third side, the one we were approaching, was the moat. It was a deep, murky waterway that surrounded the entire park, and Margo had deemed it the most challenging obstacle to overcome. The water was home to a variety of marine life, including alligators, snakes, and fish with razor-sharp teeth. We had to navigate this treacherous waterway without being seen, and Margo had planned a route that would take us under the cover of darkness, using the shadows of the trees and the park's infrastructure to conceal our movements. As we stood at the edge of the moat, I could feel my heart racing with anticipation and fear. Margo handed me a small, waterproof bag containing a pair of flippers, a snorkel, and a mask. "Put these on," she said, her voice low and steady. "We need to move quickly and quietly." I hesitated for a moment, unsure if I was ready for this, but Margo's determination was infectious, and I soon found myself donning the gear and following her into the unknown. The water was colder than I expected, and it took a few moments for me to adjust to the sensation of being submerged. But as I looked up at Margo, I saw that she was already swimming away from the edge, her movements smooth and efficient. I took a deep breath and followed her, trying to mimic her strokes and keep up with her pace. The water was dark and murky, but I could see the faint glow of the park's lights in the distance, and I knew we were getting closer to our goal. As we swam, I couldn't help but think about the risks we were taking. If we got caught, we would be in serious trouble. But Margo seemed to know what she was doing, and I trusted her instincts. We swam in silence for what felt like hours, the only sound being the gentle lapping of the water against our bodies. Finally, Margo signaled for us to stop, and we hovered in the water, listening for any signs of movement. The silence was oppressive, and I strained my ears to pick up any sound. But there was nothing. It was as if we were the only ones in the world. Margo gave me a nod, and we continued on, our movements slow and deliberate. We were getting close, I could feel it. The water was shallower now, and I could see the outline of the park's buildings looming in the distance. We were almost there. But as we swam closer, I realized that we weren't alone. There was something in the water with us, something big and powerful. I tried to push the thought aside, but it lingered in the back of my mind, making my heart beat faster. Margo seemed to sense my fear, and she reached out to grab my arm, her grip firm but reassuring. "It's okay," she whispered. "We're almost there." But as we swam closer to the shore, I knew that we were far from safe. The water was getting shallower, and I could see the outline of a figure standing on the edge of the moat, watching us. My heart skipped a beat as I realized that we had been seen. Margo's grip on my arm tightened, and she pulled me closer to her. "Stay calm," she whispered. "We need to get out of here, now." But it was too late. The figure had already raised its voice, shouting for help. We were caught, and our adventure was about to take a deadly turn.

The memory of that man still lingered, a cautionary tale told to new recruits to remind them of the risks they took every time they stepped into the tank. It was a sobering thought, one that weighed heavily on the minds of the men as they prepared for their shift, their hearts racing with anticipation and fear. The tank loomed before them, a massive steel behemoth that seemed to pulse with an otherworldly energy, its surface glinting in the sunlight like a malevolent eye. As they geared up and climbed into their suits, the air was thick with tension, the only sound the hiss of the airlocks and the creak of the metal as the tank's massive doors swung open, revealing the dark, foreboding interior. The men exchanged nervous glances, their faces set with determination, their eyes fixed on the task ahead. They knew what was at stake, and they were ready to face it head-on, but deep down, they couldn't shake the feeling that they were walking into a nightmare from which they might not awaken.

I stood up, splashed some more water on my face, and looked at myself in the mirror again. This time, I saw a person who looked tired, worried, and unsure of what the future held. I could control how I reacted to this situation, and how I chose to move forward. I could control my own thoughts, my own emotions, and my own actions. And with that realization, I felt a sense of determination wash over me. I was ready to face whatever came next, and to take control of my life.

es_second_half: la pared y me quedé dormido. El sueño duró unos dieciséis milisegundos, hasta que sonó el timbre de la segunda hora. Me levanté y me dirigí a clase de latín, luego a física y por fin llegó la hora de comer. Encontré a Ben en la cafetería. —Necesito una siesta —le dije.

es_results_raw: mi espalda en la pared y me quedé allí sentado durante unos minutos, tratando de calmarme. La idea que me había venido a la mente era que tal vez, si me quedaba quieto lo suficiente, podría escuchar algo. Al principio, solo oía el sonido de mi respiración y el ruido de la lluvia que caía afuera. Pero luego, después de un rato, comencé a escuchar algo más. Un susurro, un murmullo, un ruido débil que parecía provenir de la pared opuesta. Me quedé allí sentado, con la oreja pegada a la pared, tratando de escuchar mejor. Y entonces, de repente, la voz se hizo más clara. Era una voz femenina, suave y melodiosa, que parecía estar hablando conmigo. Me sentí un escalofrío recorrer mi espalda y mi corazón comenzó a latir con fuerza. ¿Quién era esa voz? ¿Qué quería decirme? Me quedé allí sentado, con la oreja pegada a la pared, tratando de escuchar cada palabra, cada sonido, cada susurro. La voz parecía estar hablando de algo importante, algo que solo yo podía escuchar. Me sentí atraído por la voz, como si estuviera siendo llamado hacia algo. Y entonces, de repente, la voz se calló. Me quedé allí sentado, en silencio, esperando a que volviera a hablar. Pero no volvió a hablar. Me quedé allí sentado durante un rato, tratando de procesar lo que había escuchado. ¿Había sido solo mi imaginación? ¿O había sido algo real? No lo sabía, pero sabía que nunca olvidaría ese momento. La voz me había dejado con una sensación de misterio, de incertidumbre. Y me sentí atraído a seguir investigando, a descubrir qué había detrás de esa voz. Así que me levanté del retrete, me lavé la cara y salí del baño, decidido a seguir adelante.

en_first_half: That night, I lay on my side, staring out the window into the invisible world outside. I kept trying to fall asleep, but then my eyes would dart open,
en_second_half: just to check. I couldn’t help but hope that Margo Roth Spiegelman would return to my window and drag my tired ass through one more night I’d never forget.
en_results: The darkness outside seemed to be calling to me, its silence a stark contrast to the chaos that swirled in my mind. I thought about all the things I had to
en_results_raw: The darkness outside seemed to be calling to me, its silence a stark contrast to the chaos that swirled in my mind. I thought about all the things I had to do tomorrow, the deadlines I had to meet, the people I had to see, and the places I had to be. My mind was a jumble of thoughts, each one vying for attention, making it impossible for me to relax. I tossed and turned, trying to find a comfortable position, but my body felt heavy, weighed down by the weight of my own thoughts. Just as I was starting to drift off, a faint noise caught my attention, a creak of the old wooden floorboards outside my room. I froze, my heart racing, wondering if someone was there, watching me, waiting for me to make a move. The silence that followed was oppressive, making me feel like I was holding my breath, waiting for something to happen. And then, just as suddenly as it had started, everything was quiet again, leaving me feeling more awake than ever, my senses on high alert, my mind racing with possibilities.

Tôi nhìn thấy những bóng tối u ám đang di chuyển trên tường, như những con quỷ đang cố gắng xâm nhập vào phòng của tôi. Tôi cố gắng không để ý, nhưng không thể tránh khỏi cảm giác sợ hãi và bất an. Tôi biết rằng tôi không thể ngủ được, và tôi phải chờ đợi cho đến sáng sớm để thoát khỏi cơn ác mộng này. Nhưng khi tôi nhìn ra ngoài cửa sổ, tôi thấy một hình ảnh kỳ lạ, một hình ảnh của một người phụ nữ đang đứng trên nóc nhà, nhìn vào tôi với một nụ cười bí ẩn. es_results_raw: cerraban cada vez que intentaba cerrarlos, y mi mente se llenaba de pensamientos sobre el misterioso lugar que se extendía más allá de la oscuridad. La luna llena brillaba en el cielo, proyectando sombras que bailaban en las paredes de mi habitación, y yo me sentía atraído por la tentación de salir a explorar. La noche era silenciosa, solo interrumpida por el canto de un búho en la distancia, y me sentí como si estuviera a punto de descubrir un secreto que había estado escondido durante años. La cama se me hacía pesada, y mi cuerpo se sentía inquieto, como si estuviera listo para saltar de la cama y correr hacia la libertad. La ventana se me antojaba una puerta a un mundo desconocido, y yo estaba decidido a cruzarla, a ver qué secretos y misterios me esperaban en el otro lado.

The flickering fluorescent lights above cast an eerie glow on the rows of books, making it seem as though the very walls were alive, watching me as I moved through the space. I ran my fingers over the spines of the books, feeling the raised letters and the worn covers, and a shiver ran down my spine as I realized that I was not alone in the library. I could have sworn I heard a faint whisper, a soft murmur that seemed to be coming from the shelf to my left, where a particular book seemed to be calling out to me.

Y en ese momento, la idea de la muerte no es algo aterradora, sino algo natural, algo que forma parte de la gran danza de la vida. Me pregunto si Whitman habría querido que su poesía fuera una forma de preparar a los demás para la muerte, de enseñarles a verla como algo que no es el fin, sino un nuevo comienzo. La idea me parece fascinante, y me hace pensar en la importancia de la poesía como herramienta para entender y abordar la muerte de manera más profunda. La poesía de Whitman es un recordatorio de que la vida es breve, pero también es un llamado a vivirla al máximo, a disfrutar de cada momento, a encontrar la belleza en la naturaleza y en la conexión con los demás. Me pregunto si Whitman habría querido que su poesía fuera un legado que perdurara más allá de su muerte, un recordatorio de la importancia de vivir en armonía con la naturaleza y con los demás seres humanos. en_results_raw: drifting from town to town, never staying in one place for too long, always keeping a low profile. She'd be a ghost, invisible and free, with the world spread out before her like an endless map. And the books would be her guide, her confidants, her ticket to a life of adventure and escape. She'd read about the Grand Canyon, the Great Barrier Reef, the ancient ruins of Machu Picchu, and the vibrant cities of Tokyo and Paris. She'd dream of the freedom to roam, to explore, to discover new wonders and marvels. And with each new destination, she'd feel a thrill of excitement, a sense of possibility, a sense of being alive. But as the days turned into weeks, and the weeks turned into months, she'd begin to feel a pang of loneliness, a sense of disconnection from the world she left behind. She'd wonder if anyone was looking for her, if anyone even missed her. And so she'd keep moving, always moving, never staying in one place for too long, always keeping a watchful eye over her shoulder, waiting for the day when she could finally feel safe, finally feel free.

es_results_raw: sin que nadie la viera, sin que nadie supiera dónde estaba. Imaginaba el sabor de la libertad en su boca, el viento en su cabello y el sol en su rostro. Y también imaginaba el miedo que sentiría al principio, el miedo a lo desconocido, a lo que podría pasar. Pero Margo no era una persona que se dejara intimidar fácilmente. Había superado obstáculos antes y había salido adelante. Así que, con cada página que leía, se sentía más decidida, más segura de que podría hacerlo. Podría dejar atrás su vida anterior y empezar de cero en algún lugar lejano, donde nadie la conociera y nadie la juzgara. Podría ser alguien nueva, alguien que no tuviera secretos ni miedos. Y aunque no sabía qué le depararía el futuro, sabía que estaba lista para enfrentarlo. La idea de viajar se había convertido en una obsesión para ella, una llama que ardía cada vez más fuerte en su interior. Y no había nada que la apagara.

Había la caja de cartas que había escrito en el camino, la cámara de fotos que había tomado en la cima de la montaña, y el mapa que había trazado en la playa. Me detuve frente a la ventana y miré hacia fuera, intentando ver a Margo en la naturaleza, pero no la vi. Sin embargo, sentí su presencia, como si estuviera allí, esperándome. Me sentí más decidido que nunca a encontrarla y a descubrir el secreto que la rodeaba.

I tried to push the thoughts aside, to focus on the present moment, but they lingered, haunting me like a ghost in the shadows. And then, I heard her voice, soft and sweet, calling out to me from the other room, "Are you okay?" It was a question that seemed innocent enough, but I knew better. It was a test, a way for her to gauge my reaction, to see how far I'd go before I snapped. I took a deep breath, trying to calm my racing heart, and replied, "Yeah, I'm fine." en_second_half: room at the same time, and I felt a ripple of nausea—maybe they had bad news about Margo—before I remembered it was my graduation day.
en_results: completion> room at the same time, and I knew something was up. My mom was holding a small suitcase and my dad had a peculiar look on his
en_results_raw: completion> room at the same time, and I knew something was up. My mom was holding a small suitcase and my dad had a peculiar look on his face, like he was trying to hide a secret. "Good morning, kiddo," my mom said, trying to sound casual, but I could sense the excitement beneath her tone. "We have some news to share with you," my dad added, setting the suitcase down on the bed. I felt a mix of curiosity and apprehension as I looked at them, wondering what this news could be. My parents exchanged a glance, and my mom took a deep breath before speaking up. "We've been thinking a lot about our next adventure, and we've decided to take a family trip to Europe," she said, a big smile spreading across her face. I was taken aback, unsure of what to say or do. A trip to Europe sounded amazing, but it also meant leaving behind my friends, school, and the comfort of our routine. My dad chimed in, "We've always wanted to explore the continent together as a family, and we think this is the perfect opportunity. We'll be visiting Paris, Rome, and Barcelona, and we want you to be a part of it." I couldn't help but feel a surge of excitement at the prospect of traveling to these incredible cities, but I also had a lot of questions and concerns. "When are we leaving?" I asked, trying to process this sudden change in plans. My parents exchanged another glance, and my mom replied, "We're leaving in two weeks, so we need to start making arrangements and packing our bags."
